question: Which mineral is black, has a nonmetallic luster, and can be scratched with a fingernail?

content.source_1: Observation of the unknown: The sample is black, has a nonmetallic luster in hand sample, and can be scratched with a fingernail.
content.source_2: Reference sheet entry for biotite (mica): Biotite is a black to dark-brown mica with nonmetallic luster, perfect cleavage into thin elastic sheets, and hardness around 2â€“3 on the Mohs scale.
content.source_3: Classification practice on standard high school mineral tables (e.g., NYS Earth Science): Luster is used as the first split; graphite is listed on the metallic-luster side (steel gray to black color, hardness ~1, marks paper).
content.source_4: Additional observation of the unknown: The sample leaves a dark gray to black streak on unglazed porcelain, readily writes on paper like a pencil, and feels greasy, smudging the fingers.
content.source_5: Graphite diagnostic note: Although commonly described with a metallic luster, graphite can appear dull/earthy (nonmetallic) in massive or sooty forms; its black streak and ability to write on paper are diagnostic.
content.source_6: Mica group property note: Mica minerals split into flexible, elastic sheets; biotite is the common black mica in igneous and metamorphic rocks and is readily identified by its sheet-like cleavage.
